--- title: "When Do Networks Create Value?" subtitle: "Social Capital, Brokerage, and Business Performance" author: "SMM638 Network Analytics" format: revealjs: theme: default slide-number: true transition: slide chalkboard: true multiplex: false css: ../../slideshow-theme.css code-fold: true code-summary: "" jupyter: python3 --- ## The Leading Question ::: {.fragment} ::: {.callout-important icon=false style="font-size: 1.4em;"} When do networks create value for individuals and organizations? ::: ::: ::: {.fragment} This question drives network theory's investigation into **how structural position translates into tangible outcomes**. ::: ## A Theoretical Framework | | **Social Capital** | **Social Homogeneity** | |--------------------------|---------------------------------------|------------------------| | **Network Flow** | **Capitalization (Value Creation)** | Contagion | | **Network Architecture** | Coordination | Adaptation (Network Change) | ::: {style="margin-top: 30px; text-align: center; color: #555;"} Our focus today: How network position creates value through **social capital** mechanisms ::: ::: aside Source: Scott (2011), SAGE Handbook of Social Network Analysis, p. 47 ::: ## Two Theories of Network Value {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="48%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); color: #000; padding: 30px; border-radius: 8px; font-size: 1.2em; min-height: 340px;"} **Bridging Social Capital** Sparse networks bring value through access to **diverse information** and new opportunities. *Mechanism:* Network Brokerage *Key scholar:* Ron Burt (U. of Chicago) ::: ::: ::: {.column width="4%"} ::: ::: {.column width="48%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(153, 153, 153, 0.2); color: #000; padding: 30px; border-radius: 8px; font-size: 1.2em; min-height: 340px;"} **Bonding Social Capital** Dense networks create value by fostering **trust** and enabling cooperation. *Mechanism:* Network Closure *Key scholar:* James Coleman (Columbia U.) ::: ::: :::: ## Part One: Bonding Social Capital ::: {.callout-note icon=false appearance="minimal" style="font-size: 1.2em"} How dense networks create value through closure and trust ::: ## What is Network Closure? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {.definition style="background: rgba(153, 153, 153, 0.15); border: 2px solid #c41c85; border-radius: 6px; padding: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} **Definition** Network closure is the tendency for a network to present **direct ties between pairs of nodes**, creating dense, interconnected structures. ::: **Key insight:** When your friends know each other, information travels in closed loops. This creates an environment where: - Reputation effects can operate - Social norms can be enforced - Trust can be established and maintained ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {#1898cbc5 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import networkx as nx import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # Color palette: black, magenta, gray BLACK = '#000000' MAGENTA = '#c41c85' GRAY = '#999999' # Create a fully connected network G = nx.complete_graph(5) labels = {i: chr(65+i) for i in range(5)} # A, B, C, D, E fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(4, 4)) pos = nx.circular_layout(G) nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, edge_color=GRAY, width=1.5, alpha=0.7, ax=ax) nx.draw_networkx_nodes(G, pos, node_color=MAGENTA, node_size=500, ax=ax) nx.draw_networkx_labels(G, pos, labels, font_color='white', font_weight='bold', font_size=10, ax=ax) ax.set_title('High-Closure Network', fontweight='bold', color=BLACK) ax.axis('off') plt.tight_layout() plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/cell-2-output-1.png){width=374 height=374 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## How Closure Creates Value :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); color: #000; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} **Trust & Cooperation** Dense networks enable reciprocity. If A cheats B, mutual friend C will learn and sanction A. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); color: #000; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} **Reputation Effects** Bad behavior spreads quickly. Cheating becomes "unbearable when mutual friends uncover the deceit." ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); color: #000; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} **Norm Enforcement** Closed networks establish and enforce shared expectations, reducing uncertainty in transactions. ::: ::: :::: ::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal" style="margin-top: 30px; background: rgba(153, 153, 153, 0.15)"} *"Embedded ties protect the integrity of social and economic transactions."* â€” Coleman's view of social capital ::: ## Measuring Closure: Clustering Coefficient :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} For a node $i$ with degree $k_i$, the **clustering coefficient** is: $$C_i = \frac{2L_i}{k_i(k_i - 1)}$$ where $L_i$ = number of links between the $k_i$ neighbors of node $i$
**Interpretation:** What proportion of my friends' possible friendships actually exist? ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {#579b4a69 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} import networkx as nx import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np # Color palette: black, magenta, gray BLACK = '#000000' MAGENTA = '#c41c85' GRAY = '#999999' # Three examples of clustering # C = 0: star graph, no edges between neighbors G1 = nx.Graph() G1.add_edges_from([(0,1), (0,2), (0,3)]) colors1 = [MAGENTA, BLACK, BLACK, BLACK] # C = 1/3: one edge between neighbors G2 = nx.Graph() G2.add_edges_from([(0,1), (0,2), (0,3), (1,2)]) colors2 = [MAGENTA, BLACK, BLACK, BLACK] # C = 1: all neighbors connected G3 = nx.Graph() G3.add_edges_from([(0,1), (0,2), (0,3), (1,2), (2,3), (1,3)]) colors3 = [MAGENTA, BLACK, BLACK, BLACK] fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 3, figsize=(9, 3)) # Star layout with center at origin def star_layout(G): pos = {0: (0, 0)} neighbors = list(G.neighbors(0)) for i, n in enumerate(neighbors): angle = 2 * np.pi * i / len(neighbors) - np.pi/2 pos[n] = (0.8 * np.cos(angle), 0.8 * np.sin(angle)) return pos for ax, G, colors, title in [(axes[0], G1, colors1, 'C = 0'), (axes[1], G2, colors2, 'C = 1/3'), (axes[2], G3, colors3, 'C = 1')]: pos = star_layout(G) nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, edge_color=GRAY, width=1.5, ax=ax) nx.draw_networkx_nodes(G, pos, node_color=colors, node_size=400, ax=ax) ax.set_title(title, fontweight='bold', color=BLACK) ax.axis('off') plt.tight_layout() plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/cell-3-output-1.png){width=854 height=278 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: [Center node (magenta) with three neighbors (black)]{style="font-size: 0.8em; color: #666; text-align: center; display: block;"} ::: :::: ## Part Two: Bridging Social Capital ::: {.callout-note appearrnce="minimal" style="font-size: 1.2em"} How sparse networks create value through brokerage and information access ::: ## The Strength of Weak Ties :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(153, 153, 153, 0.2); border-radius: 6px; padding: 18px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} **Granovetter's Discovery (1973)** Job seekers found new positions through **acquaintances** rather than close friendsâ€”people they saw "occasionally" or "rarely." ::: **Why?** Your close friends know what you know. - Strong ties move in overlapping social circles - Information from friends is often *redundant* - Weak ties connect to *different* social worlds - Each acquaintance provides unique, non-overlapping information ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {#94181d6d .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} import networkx as nx import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np # Color palette: black, magenta, gray BLACK = '#000000' MAGENTA = '#c41c85' GRAY = '#999999' # Create a network showing weak ties bridging communities G = nx.Graph() edges = [ (0,1), (0,2), (1,2), # Left cluster (strong ties) (0,3), # Weak tie bridge (3,4), (3,5), (4,5), # Right cluster (strong ties) (0,6), # Another weak tie (6,7), (6,8) # Another cluster ] G.add_edges_from(edges) # Edge styles: weak ties are dashed strong_edges = [(0,1), (0,2), (1,2), (3,4), (3,5), (4,5), (6,7), (6,8)] weak_edges = [(0,3), (0,6)] # Node colors and sizes node_colors = [MAGENTA] + [BLACK]*8 node_sizes = [500] + [300]*8 fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(5, 4)) np.random.seed(42) pos = nx.spring_layout(G, seed=42) # Draw strong edges (solid) nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, edgelist=strong_edges, edge_color=GRAY, width=2, alpha=0.7, ax=ax) # Draw weak edges (dashed) nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, edgelist=weak_edges, edge_color=GRAY, width=1, style='dashed', alpha=0.7, ax=ax) # Draw nodes nx.draw_networkx_nodes(G, pos, node_color=node_colors, node_size=node_sizes, ax=ax) ax.set_title('Weak Ties Bridge Communities', fontweight='bold', color=BLACK) ax.axis('off') plt.tight_layout() plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/cell-4-output-1.png){width=470 height=374 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: [Dashed lines = weak ties spanning clusters]{style="font-size: 0.8em; color: #666; text-align: center; display: block;"} ::: :::: ::: aside Source: Granovetter (1973), "The Strength of Weak Ties," *American Journal of Sociology* ::: ## Structural Holes: Burt's Framework :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {.definition style="background: rgba(153, 153, 153, 0.15); border: 2px solid #c41c85; border-radius: 6px; padding: 18px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} **Definition** A **structural hole** is the "empty space" in a network between two sets of nodes that do not otherwise interact closely. ::: **Individuals who span structural holes gain:** :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.12); padding: 12px; border-radius: 4px;"} **Information** Early access to diverse, non-redundant knowledge ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.12); padding: 12px; border-radius: 4px;"} **Control** Ability to broker and synthesize across groups ::: ::: :::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {#171ac919 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} import networkx as nx import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # Color palette: black, magenta, gray BLACK = '#000000' MAGENTA = '#c41c85' GRAY = '#999999' DARK_GRAY = '#555555' # Create structural hole visualization G = nx.Graph() edges = [ (0,1), (0,2), (1,2), (1,3), (2,3), # Left cluster (4,5), (4,6), (5,6), (5,7), (6,7), # Right cluster (3,8), (7,8) # Broker connections ] G.add_edges_from(edges) # Node colors: left cluster (black), right cluster (dark gray), broker (magenta) node_colors = [BLACK]*4 + [DARK_GRAY]*4 + [MAGENTA] node_sizes = [300]*8 + [600] labels = {8: 'B'} # Fixed positions pos = { 0: (-2, 1), 1: (-2, 0), 2: (-1.5, 0.5), 3: (-1, 0), 4: (2, 1), 5: (2, 0), 6: (1.5, 0.5), 7: (1, 0), 8: (0, 0) } fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(5, 4)) nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, edge_color=GRAY, width=1.5, ax=ax) nx.draw_networkx_nodes(G, pos, node_color=node_colors, node_size=node_sizes, ax=ax) nx.draw_networkx_labels(G, pos, labels, font_color='white', font_weight='bold', font_size=12, ax=ax) ax.set_title('Broker Spanning Structural Hole', fontweight='bold', color=BLACK) ax.axis('off') plt.tight_layout() plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](slideshow_files/figure-revealjs/cell-5-output-1.png){width=470 height=374 fig-align='center'} ::: ::: [Node B spans the gap between two clusters]{style="font-size: 0.8em; color: #666; text-align: center; display: block;"} ::: :::: ::: aside Source: Burt (1992), *Structural Holes: The Social Structure of Competition* ::: ## The Brokerage Advantage :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); color: #000; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} **1. Non-Redundant Information** Brokers access information from multiple, unconnected sourcesâ€”each providing unique knowledge. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); color: #000; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} **2. Early Access** Information reaches brokers first because they sit at the intersection of communication flows. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); color: #000; padding: 20px; border-radius: 8px;"} **3. Strategic Control** Brokers can regulate information flow, synthesize ideas across groups, and create new combinations. ::: ::: :::: ::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"} ðŸ’¡ *"People with networks rich in structural holes have better ideas."* â€” Ron Burt, research on managers at a large electronics company ::: ::: aside Source: Burt (2004), "Structural Holes and Good Ideas," *American Journal of Sociology* ::: ## Measuring Brokerage Position {.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {style="background: rgba(196, 28, 133, 0.15); border-radius: 6px; padding: 16px; margin-bottom: 20px;"} **Betweenness Centrality** How often does a node lie on the shortest path between others? $$C_B(i) = \sum_{j
